animalOfTheDay.name: ape
facts: They share 96-99% of their DNA with humans depending on the species.
Great apes can learn and use sign language to communicate with humans.
They recognize themselves in mirrors, showing self-awareness.
Apes make tools and pass knowledge down through generations.

calendar.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.
They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.
Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.
Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.

calendar.name: zebu
facts: Zebus have humps storing fat for drought survival – not water.
They sweat insect-repellent oils and tolerate heat better than European cattle.
Zebu are sacred in India – 330 million gods are said to live in each.
Their loose skin helps dissipate heat in tropical climates.

calendar.name: zonkey
facts: Zonkeys are zebra-donkey hybrids; stripes typically appear only on legs.
They inherit donkey calmness with zebra hardiness against diseases.
Their bray combines zebra whinny and donkey 'hee-haw'.
Zonkeys are sterile due to mismatched chromosomes.

calendar.name: aardvark
facts: Their name comes from Afrikaans meaning 'earth pig' though they're not related to pigs.
They have incredibly strong claws that can dig through concrete.
Aardvarks can eat up to 50,000 ants and termites in a single night.
Baby aardvarks are called cubs and stay with their mothers for about 6 months.

calendar.name: alligator
facts: A mother alligator carries her babies to water in her mouth after they hatch.
They're one of the few animals that continue growing throughout their entire lives.
They can survive up to 2-3 years without eating in extreme conditions.
Alligators can hold their breath underwater for up to 24 hours.

calendar.name: anteater
facts: Giant anteaters can consume up to 30,000 ants and termites per day.
They have no teeth but use their sticky 2-foot-long tongues to catch prey.
Their sense of smell is 40 times stronger than humans.
Baby anteaters ride on their mother's back for up to 10 months.

calendar.name: ape
facts: They recognize themselves in mirrors, showing self-awareness.
They share 96-99% of their DNA with humans depending on the species.
Apes make tools and pass knowledge down through generations.
Great apes can learn and use sign language to communicate with humans.

randomAnimals.name: narwhal
facts: Narwhals are known as the 'unicorns of the sea' due to their long, spiral tusks.
The tusk is actually an elongated tooth with up to 10 million nerve endings.
Narwhals can dive up to 5,000 feet and hold their breath for 25 minutes.
They live only in Arctic waters and are rarely seen in captivity.

randomAnimals.name: agama
facts: They are very fast and agile lizards that can climb rocks and trees.
Agamas are lizards found in Africa, Asia, and Europe, known for their ability to change color depending on their mood and temperature.
Male agamas can take on bright colors during the breeding season to attract females.
They live in various environments, from deserts to forests, and are omnivorous.

randomAnimals.name: wasp
facts: Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.
